question: What safety modes does the robot arm have?
gold_answer: The robot arm has three safety modes. Normal mode, reduced mode, and recovery mode.

question: What happens if my robot stopped in 1000ms when my stopping time safety limit is set to 200ms?
gold_answer: The robot arm will enter recovery mode because the safety limits have been violated.

question: What mode do I need to be in to load a program?
gold_answer: You need to be in Automatic Mode to load and execute a program, but you need to be in manual mode to modify and create new programs.

question: How can I set up my active program so that I only need to modify 1 or 2 variables each run?
gold_answer: If you only want to modify 1 or 2 variables during each run of a program, you can favorite specific program variables so you can access them easier and not go through other variables.

question: What are the network configuration requirements to use the network features of the robot?
gold_answer: The network requirements suggest that only trusted devices should be connected to the local area network. There must be no inbound connections from adjacent networks to the robot, outgoing connections from the robot are to be restricted to allow the smallest relevant set of specific ports, protocols and addresses. Only URCaps and magic scripts from trusted partners can be used and only after verifying their authenticity and integrity.

question: The safety settings in the configuration wont let me change certain settings? Why not?
gold_answer: If the safety settings are not letting you change them, there is likely a safety password previous set. Once you enter the password and press "Unlock" the settings should be accessible.

question: How do I set the admin password?
gold_answer: Go to the settings, tap "admin" under "password", enter "easybot" into the "Current Password" option. Enter the new password under "new password" and "confirm new password". Then tap Apply to confirm the change/set.

question: What network protocols for real-time control does the robot accept?
My robot is close to a collision and if I restart it, it may cause another collision from the vibrations. What can I do?
gold_answer: You can use backdrive. In backdrive manual mode, you can use force to move specific joints to a desired position without releasing all brakes in the arm.

question: Is it ok to use any type of packaging to move the arm if I want to transport it?
gold_answer: No, not using the original packaging when transporting the arm will void the warranty. If you want to transport the robot please follow the standard procedure for doing so and use the original packing the arm came in.

question: I used to use an old robot arm, which I had to constantly test the stopping performance for every use, do I have to do that with this arm?
gold_answer: No. So long as you have the stop distance safety functions used, the robot arm will do continuous monitoring of its own stopping performance and will enter recovery mode if it fails during monitoring.

question: How do I clean the machine?
gold_answer: Prepare the surface by removing loose dirt or debris. Apply a cleaning agent to the surface that needs cleaning, agitater the agent for stubborn spots, let the agent rest on the surface for 5 minutes, rinse the system with water, and leave the machine out to air dry, or dry using towels.

question: Can I use bleach as a cleaning agent? What should I use instead?
gold_answer: You should not use bleach as a cleaning solution for this arm. The recommended agents you can use include water, 70% isopropyl alcohol, 10% ethanol alcohol, and 10% naphtha to remove grease.

question: I got some grease on my arm while cleaning. Is that ok?
gold_answer: No, grease is an irritant and can cause an allergic reaction. Wash the area with water and a mild cleaning agent to reduce risk of a reaction.

question: How do I power down the robot arm?
gold_answer: Press the power button on the TP to turn off the robot, then unplug the power cord from the wall socket and give it 30 seconds to discharge any stored energy.
